description.narrative: The overall objective of the project is to introduce a set of comprehensive measures to help restore the Strumica River Basin’s socio-ecological functions and increase its overall resilience to pressures resulting from human activities and global changes

activity-description.narrative: The region of Strumica Watershed - 6 municipalities in South-East planning region

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

1. Construction of the second wastewater management system in the village of Edrinikovo, Municipality of Vasilevo has been launched. Works are expected to be completed in the first half of 2018, when a population of app. 50 people will have access to high quality wastewater collection and treatment service.
2. Building upon the achievements of the first grants cycle targeting Basin’s fruit and vegetable producers, the project has completed the second cycle. The training programme provided the selected farmers with the knowledge and skills they need to shift farming toward more sustainable practices. Thirty farmers received grants in equipment for implementation of sustainable farming practices. Selected farmers specialize in modern fruit and vegetable farming, pest management, irrigation and fertigation, soil management and plant nutrition, as well as contemporary greenhouse production. Improved farming practices bring about encouraging changes in terms of use of agro-chemicals and irrigation water. For example, some of the fruit and vegetable farms that previously irrigated by using outdated furrow systems have tripled water use efficiency thanks to the newly installed drip irrigation and scheduling systems, based on the use of sensor data for soil and local climate. Besides the obvious environmental effects, these changes are highly favorable from a production and economic point of view (because of increased yields and better-quality products).
3. UNDP is providing technical assistance to water management authorities to achieve improved operation of the existing dams/reservoirs for better flood control. Following the development of sophisticated reservoir optimization models, trainings are underway targeting responsible operating staff of the Turija and Vodoca dams for the use of these models in regular management activities. These include, for example, maintaining optimal water levels in the reservoirs in different seasons of the year in order to maximize flood control, and also securing sufficient quantities of water for the remaining purposes (irrigation and water supply). Improving the flood control effects of existing systems is highly beneficial from an environmental and economic point of view (e.g., avoiding additional investments in new flood control structures and avoiding corresponding operation and maintenance costs). The full use of these optimization models being made possible thanks to the improved meteorological and hydrological monitoring. This now allows dam operators to implement for more dynamic management of water levels in reservoirs, thus balancing the competing demands of their operation. The newly installed water level gauges on both reservoirs provide valuable information that’s being used both by the water management authority and the Hydro-meteorological Service.
4. A basin-scale early warning system for floods is being piloted in the Strumica River Basin. The system provides timely warning of future floods so that adequate measures can be taken by institutions and communities in order to avoid/prevent damage to property and save lives. These efforts for introducing new capacity are complemented with ongoing measures to improve the monitoring network and the activating of a basin-scale meteorological and hydrological monitoring network. The recently introduced monitoring system comprising seven meteorological monitoring stations, as well as three hydrological monitoring stations is fully operational. The project is supporting relevant institutions to maintain real-time information exchange, including the newly generated monitoring data, for better river basin and flood risk management in future, as well as functioning of an early warning system for floods.

1. Setting grounds for phased industrial pollution reduction through strengthening administrative capacities for environmental permitting and raising community awareness 2. Defining long-term basin-scale wastewater management strategy 3. Initiation of a multi-year transformative programme for adopting agro-ecological farming practices 4. Developing planning base for reducing flood risks in the Strumica River Basin to acceptable levels 5. Piloting comprehensive basin-scale water monitoring programme aligned with the principles of the EU Water Framework Directive

1. Thanks to the project’s capacity development programme, the responsible municipal personnel and the Basin’s major industrial operators have improved their skills and knowledge on integrated pollution prevention and control. A total of 16 nominated environmental permitting officials from all six Basin municipalities have undergone a comprehensive on-the-job training on integrated pollution prevention and control. Also number of industry operators and environmental NGOs took part in the programme that has been co-designed in a way to overcome some of the key barriers to introducing a more effective environmental permitting system and consequently phased pollution reduction in the Basin.
2. Based on the feasibility assessment of multiple options and approaches in terms of aggregation of communities in agglomerations, wastewater treatment technologies and financial consequences, local governments of the Basin’s municipalities have engaged in a process of adopting a long-term wastewater management strategy and identifying investment priorities. These process identified and conceptualized affordable wastewater management options for about 65,000 people living in the rural communities of the Basin. This has provided the basis for long-term actions in overcoming wastewater management-related issues in the Basin that are among the key sources of pressures to water bodies.
3. A comprehensive programme has been launched to stimulate transformation of farming practices in the Basin into more contemporary approaches of agro-ecological farming and precision agriculture. The programme focuses on demonstrating more sustainable farming of selected fruits (apples, peaches and plums) and vegetables (tomatoes and peppers). The successfully completed training programme delivered to selected farmers was followed up by the selection of thirty farmer grantees who will be supported to implement new scalable and replicable farming practices on thirty pilot farms across the Basin.
4. The country’s first ever EU-based Flood Risk Management Plan has been developed for the Strumica River Basin, providing the basis for interlinked prioritized investments for mitigating flood risk and improving the overall management of water resources. The Plan introduces the concept of basin-scale risk-based flood management, providing the basis for the implementation of flood mitigation measures that will help optimize socio-economic and environmental benefits. Not only does it provide the necessary guidance to the future project-supported measures, but also already informs ongoing complementary initiatives (e.g., UNDP-backed EU Flood Recovery Programme). The hazard, risk mapping and flood risk management planning efforts are combined with the development of the optimization models for Basin’s largest dams. Once finished and applied these models, backed by improve weather forecasting, will play critical role in the retaining flood waves and protecting the downstream communities.
5. A comprehensive EU-based river basin monitoring programme has been launched for the first time in the Basin, generating valuable insights into the physical and ecological characteristics of water bodies, building a foundation for more informed future water resources and flood risk management actions. The monitoring programme provides an on-the-job training opportunity for the responsible professional of the Hydro-meteorological Service – a state institution authorized for complete water monitoring in line with EU-based principles. The replication and scaling-up potential of the newly gained knowledge is very high since the same personnel are supposed to implement similar monitoring programmes across all country’s river basins. The monitoring programme also represents a critical element of the floods early warning system that is being developed for the Basin based on the ongoing re-activation and upgrade of the meteorological and hydrological monitoring system.

The two-year capacity development programme targeting municipal authorities in charge of the Integrated Pollution Prevention and Control (IPPC) system has been successfully completed. The purpose of this support was to overcome some of the key barriers to more effective enforcement of the environmental permitting regulation focusing on industrial operators Following the successful completion of comprehensive training programme, the responsible municipal personnel applied the knowledge on industrial facilities, used as case studies. This has provided the responsible staff with additional on-the-job training experience and better access to information. Throughout a collaborative efforts of experts and municipal administration from the six municipalities, the the first ever basin-scale spatial analysis of the industrial pollution were carried out. This new data has been combined with the river basin management plan which provides the basis for building a new system for monitoring industrial pollution and tracking compliance of industrial capacities with permit conditions. Following the findings and recommendations of the Feasibility Study on Wastewater Management Options in the Strumica River Basin, advanced technical documentation for six identified agglomerations (villages of Staro Baldovci, Edrenikovo, Novo Konjarevo, Samoilovo, Robovo and Sedlarci) has been completed. This includes infrastructural and basic designs for all wastewater management systems including sewerage collection and treatment facilities. Two local communities were selected for project-backed demonstration of the two different treatment approaches (the village of Novo Konjarevo, Municipality of Novo Selo, and the village of Edrinikovo, Municipality of Vasilevo. The system was completed for the village of Novo Konjarevo benefiting a population of approximately 1000 people. For the remaining four communities, support will be provided to the local authorities to mobilize funding from different sources. One of the goals of these demonstration projects, besides solving local pollution issues, will be to showcase successful examples of decentralized treatment systems, to facilitate future replication. Following the completion of comprehensive training programme, the first group of thirty farmers were awarded grants (20 vegetable and 10 fruit producers). They were provided with the necessary equipment and expert support to pilot modern practices. The results of the programme are highly encouraging in terms of reduction in the use of agro-chemicals and water, and improving yields and quality of products. By building upon these achievements the second group of farmers was selected and they will wh are undergoing the specialized trainings and will start implemented the new set of practices during the upcoming growing season. To make the new farming knowledge more accessible to the general farmer community, the project supports the preparation of innovative training tools, including videos, animations, pocket-size manuals and mobile phone applications. All these are being co-designed with local farmers in order to make them as user-friendly as possible. Besides through small grants, an attempt to expand the area under agro-ecological practices has been made through a partnership with a major grapes producer (Agro Lozar/Dalvina) as part of a co-funding effort. The initial idea was to promote the new practices on a limited area of 2-3 hectares of a vineyard as a demonstration activity, expecting follow-up private investments to enlarge the area under more sustainable practices. However, this has matched the vineyard owner’s plans to erect new vineyards on a territory of over 20 hectares. The new set of measure implemented as part of this cooperation include: a) precise irrigation scheduling and fertilizer dosage based on soil analyses and in line with crop demand; b) solar pumping for irrigation; and c) integrated pest control based on field and weather monitoring data. The scaling-up and replication potential of this effort is significant having in mind the importance of grapes and wine production for the country. Recognizing the importance of using existing systems (e.g., dams/reservoirs) in flood risk management, the formulation of decision-support plans and policies for the operation of Turija and Vodoca – the region’s largest reservoirs was supported. The goal of this highly sophisticated modeling effort was to provide a more objective basis for the management of water levels in the reservoirs that would maximize flood control, by also securing sufficient quantities of water for the remaining purposes (irrigation and water supply). These models were discussed with the dams’ operator, and training to their responsible personnel was provided on the application of the models and use in supporting decision-making procedures. The full use of the models will be achieved if coupled with improved meteorological and hydrological monitoring as well as weather forecasting. This will allow for a more dynamic management of water levels in reservoirs thus balancing the competing demands of their operation. For this purpose, the improvements of the monitoring network, including installation of new water level gauges on both reservoirs have been supported. The first-ever comprehensive basin-scale monitoring programme is being implemented in line with the requirements of the EU Water Framework Directive (WFD) combining hydrological and ecological status parameters (physico-chemical and biological) for the previously defined water bodies. Professionals from the State Hydro-meteorological Service (HMS), backed by additional experts, benefited greatly from the newly gained knowledge that they will be able to apply in all other basins of the country, given their newly mandated responsibilities for country-wide EU WFD-based monitoring. These pioneer efforts for introducing new capacity for a basin-scale monitoring system are complemented with ongoing measures to improve the monitoring network and the activating of a basin-scale meteorological and hydrological monitoring network. Seven meteorological and three hydrological monitoring stations were made operational for this purpose. Besides the stationary monitoring stations, HMS was also provided with a modern other equipment for in-stream flow measurements on river sections without permanent hydrological monitoring or unstable eroding sections. The new equipment for water quality analyses (e.g., special microscopes for algae and zoobenthos) was also provided to the HMS laboratory. The new sophisticated hydro-meteorological monitoring network that was made operational during the reporting period provided the basis for the establishment of a basin-scale early warning system for floods (planned for the next year). A set of hydrological and meteorological stations have been connected to the national level monitoring system. The system will provide timely warning of future floods so that adequate measures can be taken by institutions and communities so to avoid/prevent damage to property and save lives. The work on the systems is already underway in cooperation with the Hydro-meteorological Services and other responsible institutions at central and local levels.
